Harley: It’s at times like this I really wish I had listened to what my mother told me.
Peter: What’d she say?
Harley: I don’t...
body:
Harley: It’s at times like this I really wish I had listened to what my mother told me.

Peter: What’d she say?

Harley: I don’t know, I didn’t listen.

title: Spider-Man for PS4 first impressions:
body:
• Really nails the emotional resonance of the character
  • Combat is not off to a great start, for a few reasons:
    • The dodge move feels like it flat out doesn’t work half the time
    • Even if it was an instant Avoid Damage button, it’s hard to tell if your Spidey Sense is warning you about the dude you’re about to punch or one of his five pals crowding around you, so it’s hard to know when to hit it
    • Enemies wielding guns are as much of a pisser as they usually are in games with brawler heroes, and Spidey introduces them way faster than the Arkham games did
    • Adding to the pool of annoying enemy types: you know how Spider-man is supposed to have superhuman agility, reflexes, and strength? I guess insomniac wasn’t clear on this, because any punk with a crowbar or lead pipe can effortlessly block a flurry of punches from him, even if he slides under his legs to try for a back attack.
    • All of the above would simply be annoying on their own, if it wasn’t for our last contestant: the brutes. The boss of the tutorial is Kingpin, a big, beefy bastard who can’t be punched normally. You have to web him up first, then get three or four punches in before he breaks out, and if you don’t web him up, he’ll chase you down and smash you with a volley of powerful punches, all of which need to be individually dodged. Fair enough, he’s a boss, and also a major, named villain. But then roaming gangs of thugs add big fellas to their roster who all behave exactly like Kingpin in combat. Every single one of my combat deaths have been to a Brute who wore me down with punches from off-screen while I was dealing with the other annoying enemy types. The game’s entire upgrade system will prove itself worthwhile if it gives me a “fuck you” counter to the brutes.
  • This version of MJ is the “girl next door” from the Raimi movies crossed with Lois Lane “reporter following a scoop into the bad guy’s lair.” I said this when Homecoming came out, I’ll say it again here: I’d love to see a Spider-man adaptation make Felicia Hardy the female lead rather than pasting MJ’s name on to what is effectively a new character altogether.
  • Another little nitpick: having the button you hold down to webswing and the button you hold down to run fast be the same button makes it kind of hard to just stop precisely where you want to. Had a bit of trouble reaching a few backpacks because of it.
  • To end on a positive note: I like that this game’s version of Detective Vision lets me chase down collectibles without constantly having to pause the game, bring up the map, and mark the closest one with a waypoint. I just click in the right stick and then swing the camera around until I see a nearby backpack/landmark icon.

blog.name: peterparkerscamera
blog.description: anna|14|masterlist|“thanos is robbing a bank”|mcu|tom holland|haz osterfield

body:
“you’re the spider-man?” | peter parker

summary; y/n finds peter’s spider-man suit and confronts him about it when he gets home.

warnings; none.

pairings; peter parker x reader

a/n; this is my first imagine, so i hope you like it!

Red and brown leaves swirled across the pavement and crunched underneath your short, black boots. A bitter breeze nipped at your ears and you pulled your grey beanie down to stop it. Arms crossed, and hands tucked into armpits, your torso was covered by a baggy orange hoodie, matching some of the fiery leaves scattered everywhere. Your breath fanned out in front of you, a whisper of fog curling into the air.

Harsh ringing disturbed the quiet. Numb fingers scrambled to open your bag. You reached for your phone, unlocked it, and accepted the call.

“Hey, Peter,” you said. The way your boyfriend’s name rolled off your tongue always made a smile fleet across your lips.

“Hi, Y/N.” There was a loud crashing sound. “Ned! What are you doing?” He chuckled at some words you could barely make out. “You haven’t left yet, have you? I’m at Ned’s, doing some project we forgot about. Did you get my text?”

“No, actually. I didn’t.” You rolled your eyes and sighed. “I’m outside your block of flats, in fact.”

Peter groaned. “Shit, I’m so sorry!”

“It’s fine,” you muttered, forcing a smile he couldn’t even see. “Is May in? It’s freezing out here.”

“Yeah. She’ll let you in. Give me half an hour and I’ll be back. I’m so sorry, Y/N,” he managed to garble out, before hanging up.

To say you were annoyed would be an understatement. Exhaling heavily through your nose, you entered the lobby and ran up the stairs in an attempt to calm yourself down. You knocked on the door and May answered almost instantly.

“Hi, Y/N! I’m just going shopping, so try not to wreck the place whilst I’m out.” Laughing, she sent you a wink.

“I’ll try my best,” you replied, offering her a fake laugh.

“We’re having Chinese tonight, if you’re interested,” she smiled. Then, she changed the subject. “I haven’t seen you here in a while.” The last sentence was more of a subtle question than a statement.

You shrugged awkwardly. “I’ve had loads of homework and this massive project for my Spanish coursework that I should have started months ago. It’s my fault, really.”

“Please stay for dinner,” May said. “It’s so nice to have more company. Well, I’ll see you later, hopefully.”

“I’ll be there,” you grinned, feeling much better than when Peter told you he would be late.

Brushing past whilst putting her coat on, May vanished down the stairs. The door shutting behind you with a gentle click, you entered the apartment. Making your way to Peter’s room, you gazed fondly at yours and his initials inside a heart engraved into his door. Softly, you traced the indentations with your fingertip. May only pretended to be annoyed when she first saw it, but secretly thought it was sweet.

A strong chemical smell hit you when you opened the door. Spluttering, you dodged all the crap on his floor and flung open a window, gulping in the fresh air. The stench was coming from his bedside cabinet, so you pulled a draw open tentatively, considering the possibility that he’d spilled something on his clothes in science, but what you discovered made you confused.

There was a clear tube with a stopper on it filled with white liquid. Around it, were little packets of chemicals and a few notes stained with said chemicals. Deciding to let Peter explain himself, you started to close the draw, and stopped when you saw the words ‘Web Fluid Version 4.02’ scrawled across a piece of paper.

Something was up. Peter never kept secrets from you. Or, so you had thought.

Curiosity overwhelmed you after a few minutes of registering everything inside your head and your attention was caught by a loose ceiling tile by the door. You gently wiggled it and it fell down, alongside a red suit, decorated with – webs?

“Peter, what the hell are you up to?” you whispered, holding up the suit to examine it.

“Y/N, what are you doing?” Peter stood in the doorframe, watching you with horror written across his face. He walked over and snatched the suit from your hands. “Why are you looking through my stuff?”

You simply gaped at him. “I-” You swallowed. “I smelt the chemicals for your ‘Web Fluid’ or whatever you called it and I wanted to know the truth.”

“Couldn’t you have asked me?” he demanded, almost angrily. “Instead of thinking: ‘Oh, let me investigate and violate my boyfriend’s privacy’?”

“Then explain yourself,” you said hotly, eyes narrowed. “But I’m not stupid, so I think you don’t need to.”

Peter collapsed onto his bed, breathing noisily in frustration. Pulling your hair anxiously, you paced his room. When the silence became unbearable, you blurted: “You’re the Spider-Man?”

He nodded slowly. There was no emotion in your voice, which scared him more than any villain could.

“You could have died, Peter,” you murmured. You raised your voice suddenly, until you were screaming. “You’re so selfish!”

Staring at you incredulously, he sat bolt upright. “I’m so what?”

“You were on the boat. You stopped the Vulture. You were at the Deli when it got pulverised. What if you had died, huh?” Your voice broke. “What about me?”

“Hey, Y/N, it’s okay.” You flung yourself into his arms and his voice faded to a quiet murmur in your ear. “I’m okay.”

You pulled away, tears streaking down your cheeks. A frown furrowed your eyebrows. “But what if you’re not?”

“Y/N, I swear, it’s okay!” Peter said, trying to pull you into his comforting embrace again.

“But I’m not okay with you risking your life. I don’t care if you say you’re safe, there’s always a chance you won’t come home. I don’t want to wake up one morning and have you kiss me goodbye and never come back because that’s too sad and I don’t want you to die, Peter.” You were crying loudly now. Sobs wracked through your body and he pulled you into his arms, stroking your hair. Your voice sounded scratched, like a broken record, when you sobbed: “Please don’t die, Peter.”

Peter gazed at you, his fingers still playing with your hair. “Y/N, look at me. I promise I won’t die. That suit is amazing and it’s saved my life more times than I care to count. Being Spider-Man makes me a hero. But I’ll always be your hero. And you’ll always be mine.”

He pressed a kiss to your forehead and cupped your jaw, making your eyes meet. Heart fluttering like a bird trapped in a cage, he wrapped his arms around you tightly, your bodies melting into each other.

“I’ll always come home, Y/N.”

reblog.comment:

“Y/N, I swear, it’s okay!” Peter said, trying to pull you into his comforting embrace again.

“But I’m not okay with you risking your life. I don’t care if you say you’re safe, there’s always a chance you won’t come home. I don’t want to wake up one morning and have you kiss me goodbye and never come back because that’s too sad and I don’t want you to die, Peter.” You were crying loudly now. Sobs wracked through your body and he pulled you into his arms, stroking your hair. Your voice sounded scratched, like a broken record, when you sobbed: “Please don’t die, Peter.”

Peter gazed at you, his fingers still playing with your hair. “Y/N, look at me. I promise I won’t die. That suit is amazing and it’s saved my life more times than I care to count. Being Spider-Man makes me a hero. But I’ll always be your hero. And you’ll always be mine.”

He pressed a kiss to your forehead and cupped your jaw, making your eyes meet. Heart fluttering like a bird trapped in a cage, he wrapped his arms around you tightly, your bodies melting into each other.

“I’ll always come home, Y/N.”

trail.content_raw:
“you’re the spider-man?” | peter parker

summary; y/n finds peter’s spider-man suit and confronts him about it when he gets home.

warnings; none.

pairings; peter parker x reader

a/n; this is my first imagine, so i hope you like it!

Red and brown leaves swirled across the pavement and crunched underneath your short, black boots. A bitter breeze nipped at your ears and you pulled your grey beanie down to stop it. Arms crossed, and hands tucked into armpits, your torso was covered by a baggy orange hoodie, matching some of the fiery leaves scattered everywhere. Your breath fanned out in front of you, a whisper of fog curling into the air.

Harsh ringing disturbed the quiet. Numb fingers scrambled to open your bag. You reached for your phone, unlocked it, and accepted the call.

“Hey, Peter,” you said. The way your boyfriend’s name rolled off your tongue always made a smile fleet across your lips.

“Hi, Y/N.” There was a loud crashing sound. “Ned! What are you doing?” He chuckled at some words you could barely make out. “You haven’t left yet, have you? I’m at Ned’s, doing some project we forgot about. Did you get my text?”

“No, actually. I didn’t.” You rolled your eyes and sighed. “I’m outside your block of flats, in fact.”

Peter groaned. “Shit, I’m so sorry!”

“It’s fine,” you muttered, forcing a smile he couldn’t even see. “Is May in? It’s freezing out here.”

“Yeah. She’ll let you in. Give me half an hour and I’ll be back. I’m so sorry, Y/N,” he managed to garble out, before hanging up.

To say you were annoyed would be an understatement. Exhaling heavily through your nose, you entered the lobby and ran up the stairs in an attempt to calm yourself down. You knocked on the door and May answered almost instantly.

“Hi, Y/N! I’m just going shopping, so try not to wreck the place whilst I’m out.” Laughing, she sent you a wink.

“I’ll try my best,” you replied, offering her a fake laugh.

“We’re having Chinese tonight, if you’re interested,” she smiled. Then, she changed the subject. “I haven’t seen you here in a while.” The last sentence was more of a subtle question than a statement.

You shrugged awkwardly. “I’ve had loads of homework and this massive project for my Spanish coursework that I should have started months ago. It’s my fault, really.”

“Please stay for dinner,” May said. “It’s so nice to have more company. Well, I’ll see you later, hopefully.”

“I’ll be there,” you grinned, feeling much better than when Peter told you he would be late.

Brushing past whilst putting her coat on, May vanished down the stairs. The door shutting behind you with a gentle click, you entered the apartment. Making your way to Peter’s room, you gazed fondly at yours and his initials inside a heart engraved into his door. Softly, you traced the indentations with your fingertip. May only pretended to be annoyed when she first saw it, but secretly thought it was sweet.

A strong chemical smell hit you when you opened the door. Spluttering, you dodged all the crap on his floor and flung open a window, gulping in the fresh air. The stench was coming from his bedside cabinet, so you pulled a draw open tentatively, considering the possibility that he’d spilled something on his clothes in science, but what you discovered made you confused.

There was a clear tube with a stopper on it filled with white liquid. Around it, were little packets of chemicals and a few notes stained with said chemicals. Deciding to let Peter explain himself, you started to close the draw, and stopped when you saw the words ‘Web Fluid Version 4.02’ scrawled across a piece of paper.

Something was up. Peter never kept secrets from you. Or, so you had thought.

Curiosity overwhelmed you after a few minutes of registering everything inside your head and your attention was caught by a loose ceiling tile by the door. You gently wiggled it and it fell down, alongside a red suit, decorated with – webs?

“Peter, what the hell are you up to?” you whispered, holding up the suit to examine it.

“Y/N, what are you doing?” Peter stood in the doorframe, watching you with horror written across his face. He walked over and snatched the suit from your hands. “Why are you looking through my stuff?”

You simply gaped at him. “I-” You swallowed. “I smelt the chemicals for your ‘Web Fluid’ or whatever you called it and I wanted to know the truth.”

“Couldn’t you have asked me?” he demanded, almost angrily. “Instead of thinking: ‘Oh, let me investigate and violate my boyfriend’s privacy’?”

“Then explain yourself,” you said hotly, eyes narrowed. “But I’m not stupid, so I think you don’t need to.”

Peter collapsed onto his bed, breathing noisily in frustration. Pulling your hair anxiously, you paced his room. When the silence became unbearable, you blurted: “You’re the Spider-Man?”

He nodded slowly. There was no emotion in your voice, which scared him more than any villain could.

“You could have died, Peter,” you murmured. You raised your voice suddenly, until you were screaming. “You’re so selfish!”

Staring at you incredulously, he sat bolt upright. “I’m so what?”

“You were on the boat. You stopped the Vulture. You were at the Deli when it got pulverised. What if you had died, huh?” Your voice broke. “What about me?”

“Hey, Y/N, it’s okay.” You flung yourself into his arms and his voice faded to a quiet murmur in your ear. “I’m okay.”

You pulled away, tears streaking down your cheeks. A frown furrowed your eyebrows. “But what if you’re not?”

“Y/N, I swear, it’s okay!” Peter said, trying to pull you into his comforting embrace again.

“But I’m not okay with you risking your life. I don’t care if you say you’re safe, there’s always a chance you won’t come home. I don’t want to wake up one morning and have you kiss me goodbye and never come back because that’s too sad and I don’t want you to die, Peter.” You were crying loudly now. Sobs wracked through your body and he pulled you into his arms, stroking your hair. Your voice sounded scratched, like a broken record, when you sobbed: “Please don’t die, Peter.”

Peter gazed at you, his fingers still playing with your hair. “Y/N, look at me. I promise I won’t die. That suit is amazing and it’s saved my life more times than I care to count. Being Spider-Man makes me a hero. But I’ll always be your hero. And you’ll always be mine.”

He pressed a kiss to your forehead and cupped your jaw, making your eyes meet. Heart fluttering like a bird trapped in a cage, he wrapped his arms around you tightly, your bodies melting into each other.

“I’ll always come home, Y/N.”
